post_text:
SSP has restructured the student support model throughout the district, including a principal and assistant principal at each site, as well as two counselors, two student support (behavior) assistants, one student support (behavior) specialist, an MTSS leader and an IB coordinator. The model allows us to continue providing the needed support and services that students, families and staff desire.

#SSPcares #SSPpride

post_text:
𝐒𝐜𝐡𝐨𝐨𝐥 𝐌𝐞𝐚𝐥 𝐔𝐩𝐝𝐚𝐭𝐞 - SSPPS is pleased to announce that school meals will be available at no charge to #SSPpride students enrolled in SSP this fall, beginning September 8 and temporarily running through December 31, 2020, but could end earlier. Please note, this is a change in original plans thanks to a U.S. Department of Agriculture waiver allowing school meals to be served free of charge to all students.

Similar to the meal boxes SSP provided this spring and summer, families can pick-up free meals for their children each week as well as for students participating in hybrid learning. At this time, meals provided at school will also be free. 𝗢𝗻𝗹𝘆 𝘀𝘁𝘂𝗱𝗲𝗻𝘁𝘀 𝘄𝗵𝗼 𝗮𝗿𝗲 𝗰𝘂𝗿𝗿𝗲𝗻𝘁𝗹𝘆 𝗲𝗻𝗿𝗼𝗹𝗹𝗲𝗱 𝗶𝗻 𝗦𝗦𝗣 𝗮𝗿𝗲 𝗲𝗹𝗶𝗴𝗶𝗯𝗹𝗲 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝗳𝗿𝗲𝗲 𝗺𝗲𝗮𝗹𝘀. 𝗙𝗮𝗺𝗶𝗹𝗶𝗲𝘀 𝘄𝗶𝗹𝗹 𝘀𝘁𝗶𝗹𝗹 𝗰𝗼𝗻𝘁𝗶𝗻𝘂𝗲 𝘁𝗼 𝗽𝗿𝗲-𝗼𝗿𝗱𝗲𝗿 𝘀𝗰𝗵𝗼𝗼𝗹 𝗺𝗲𝗮𝗹𝘀 𝗯𝘆 𝟯 𝗽.𝗺. 𝗼𝗻 𝗠𝗼𝗻𝗱𝗮𝘆𝘀.

READ DETAILS HERE - https://rb.gy/qsuqmj

First day of school is right around the corner! Make sure to pre-order school meals by 3 p.m. on Mondays.

The first week of school will be slightly different. Families can pick up a packaged school meal (includes one breakfast and one lunch) for the first day of school on Tuesday, September 8 at the designated location and time.

Families will then pick up the first week of school meals on Wednesday, September 9.

Learn more at www.sspps.org/schoolmeals2020.

post_text:
𝐇𝐨𝐰 𝐰𝐢𝐥𝐥 𝐬𝐜𝐡𝐨𝐨𝐥 𝐦𝐞𝐚𝐥𝐬 𝐛𝐞 𝐬𝐞𝐫𝐯𝐞𝐝 𝐭𝐡𝐢𝐬 𝐬𝐜𝐡𝐨𝐨𝐥 𝐲𝐞𝐚𝐫?

Glad you asked! School meals will be provided for students participating in hybrid and distance learning. All families will need to pre-order school meals by Monday 3 p.m. in order to receive school meals.

For students participating in hybrid learning, on days they are learning at school meals will be provided at school and on days they are distance learning families can pick up pre-order boxed meals on Wednesdays. Hybrid students will receive also 3-day meal boxes (three breakfasts and three lunches).

Students participating in full-time distance learning will also pre-order boxed meals. All boxed meals will be picked up on Wednesdays. and full-time distance learning will receive 5-day meal boxes (five breakfasts and five lunches).

𝙄𝙈𝙋𝙊𝙍𝙏𝘼𝙉𝙏: During the four-week soft opening when hybrid students are distance learning, families can also pre-order and pick up five days worth of meals.

Visit www.sspps.org/schoolmeals2020 to learn more.

Students participating in full-time distance learning will also pre-order boxed meals. All boxed meals will be picked up on Wednesdays. and full-time distance learning will receive 5-day meal boxes (five breakfasts and five lunches).

post_text:
SSP is the first district in the State of Minnesota to have a comprehensive K-12 IB (International Baccalaureate) program. This means in grades K-5 we focus on students being an inquirer in and out of the classroom, in grades 6-10 we focus on providing a framework for academic challenge and life skills and in grades 11-12 we focus on creativity, innovation, self-discipline and the ability to function as part of a team.

#SSPpride #SSPlearns

First day of school is right around the corner! We have three K-12 student device checkout days scheduled.

𝐇𝐚𝐯𝐞𝐧'𝐭 𝐫𝐞𝐭𝐮𝐫𝐧𝐞𝐝 𝐲𝐨𝐮𝐫 𝐝𝐞𝐯𝐢𝐜𝐞?
If your student has not yet returned their device from the 2019-20 school year or summer school, it must be returned by Friday, August 28. Those devices are disabled and will no longer be functional. You will need to return the old device prior to picking up a new device for this school year. You can drop off devices at the Kaposia, Lincoln or Secondary offices during building hours.

READ MORE details on device pick up here - http://ow.ly/t8iR50Bc3J3

#SSPpride students interested in gaining an understanding of the world of business and developing their own entrepreneurial mindset can register for the TriDistrict Business and Entrepreneurship Program.

Students learn first-hand from business leaders in our community the careers that exist in the business sector, and what it takes to succeed in areas including, but not limited to finance, marketing, sales, management, entrepreneurship, advertising, and many more.

#SSPlearns #CareerCollegeReadiness

#SSPpride 𝐂𝐨𝐦𝐦𝐮𝐧𝐢𝐭𝐲 𝐢𝐧𝐩𝐮𝐭 𝐡𝐞𝐥𝐩𝐬 𝐧𝐚𝐦𝐞 𝐧𝐞𝐰 𝐛𝐮𝐢𝐥𝐝𝐢𝐧𝐠 𝐒𝐨𝐮𝐭𝐡 𝐒𝐭. 𝐏𝐚𝐮𝐥 𝐄𝐝𝐮𝐜𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧 𝐂𝐞𝐧𝐭𝐞𝐫 - Earlier this summer, South St. Paul Public Schools asked the community for input on the name of the River Heights Professional Building they purchased last September. A naming committee, which included a number of staff and two School Board representatives, reviewed the name suggestions and brought their top recommendation to the SSP School Board. On Monday, August 10 the board approved South St. Paul Education Center as the name for the new building.

.

.
Questions? Please contact Eric Holsen at eholsen@sspps.org or call 651-457-9430.

Get your tickets today! Tickets are available at showtix4u.com/event-details/38696. A link to live streaming will be sent to you after tickets are purchased!

This is an adorable and fun musical based on a well-loved children's book. Charley is a shy child whose friends are all imaginary monsters, but he wants a real birthday party with some new real friends.

post_text:
Walking is a simple exercise that everyone can participate in; requiring little to no equipment and can be adapted to fit various environments and modified needs. StoryStroll creates a way to inspire students, caregivers and community members to be outside, support active movement and build an interest in reading.

Visit Kaposia Park with your family and participate in South Saint Paul’s first ever StoryStroll. 𝘙𝘦𝘮𝘦𝘮𝘣𝘦𝘳, 𝘸𝘩𝘪𝘭𝘦 𝘷𝘪𝘴𝘪𝘵𝘪𝘯𝘨 𝘵𝘩𝘦 𝘚𝘵𝘰𝘳𝘺𝘚𝘵𝘳𝘰𝘭𝘭 𝘴𝘵𝘢𝘺 6𝘧𝘵 𝘢𝘸𝘢𝘺 𝘧𝘳𝘰𝘮 𝘢𝘯𝘺𝘰𝘯𝘦 𝘸𝘩𝘰 𝘪𝘴 𝘯𝘰𝘵 𝘪𝘯 𝘺𝘰𝘶𝘳 𝘧𝘢𝘮𝘪𝘭𝘺.

📸Share your favorite part of the SSP StoryStroll and email it to socialmedia@sspps.org!

#SSPSummerSRTS #SSPpride #SSPcares #SSPlearns
text:
Walking is a simple exercise that everyone can participate in; requiring little to no equipment and can be adapted to fit various environments and modified needs. StoryStroll creates a way to inspire students, caregivers and community members to be outside, support active movement and build an interest in reading.

Visit Kaposia Park with your family and participate in South Saint Paul’s first ever StoryStroll. 𝘙𝘦𝘮𝘦𝘮𝘣𝘦𝘳, 𝘸𝘩𝘪𝘭𝘦 𝘷𝘪𝘴𝘪𝘵𝘪𝘯𝘨 𝘵𝘩𝘦 𝘚𝘵𝘰𝘳𝘺𝘚𝘵𝘳𝘰𝘭𝘭 𝘴𝘵𝘢𝘺 6𝘧𝘵 𝘢𝘸𝘢𝘺 𝘧𝘳𝘰𝘮 𝘢𝘯𝘺𝘰𝘯𝘦 𝘸𝘩𝘰 𝘪𝘴 𝘯𝘰𝘵 𝘪𝘯 𝘺𝘰𝘶𝘳 𝘧𝘢𝘮𝘪𝘭𝘺.

📸Share your favorite part of the SSP StoryStroll and email it to socialmedia@sspps.org!

#SSPSummerSRTS #SSPpride #SSPcares #SSPlearns

post_text:
Mark your calendars for a summer musical (online edition)!

SSP Community Theatre is proud to present its first online summer musical: The Big One-Oh!

📽 This is an adorable and fun musical based on a well-loved children's book. Charley is a shy child whose friends are all imaginary monsters, but he wants a real birthday party with some new real friends.

🗓 Performances will be online via Zoom at 2:00 p.m. and 7:00 p.m. on July 30, 31 and August 1.

🎟 Tickets are available at showtix4u.com/event-details/38696. Contact Eric Holsen at eholsen@sspps.org or (651) 457-9430 with any questions.

𝐋𝐚𝐬𝐭 𝐝𝐚𝐲 𝐭𝐨 𝐜𝐨𝐦𝐩𝐥𝐞𝐭𝐞 𝐭𝐡𝐞 𝐚𝐩𝐩𝐥𝐢𝐜𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧 𝐡𝐚𝐬 𝐛𝐞𝐞𝐧 𝐞𝐱𝐭𝐞𝐧𝐝𝐞𝐝 𝐭𝐢𝐥𝐥 𝐓𝐮𝐞𝐬𝐝𝐚𝐲, 𝐉𝐮𝐥𝐲 𝟑𝟏!

The Minnesota Department of Human Services is now offering additional funds for the families of children ages 5 to 18 who qualify for free and reduced-price meals. This new program, called Pandemic EBT (P-EBT), will provide $325 per child that families can use to purchase nutritious food for their household. Families with children who received free or reduced-price meals at school, and who were between the ages of 5 and 18 on September 1, 2019, may qualify. Benefits are available to two groups.

LEARN MORE here - https://www.sspps.org/Page/2835

If your child is entering 6th grade this fall, we encourage you to have them join us for a two-week “Packer Passport to 6th Grade” summer learning opportunity to explore the exciting experience of middle school.

The second session will be offered July 13-23, also Monday – Thursday from 9:00 – 11:00 a.m. The format will be Distance Learning and all participating students will be provided with a district device (i.e., Chromebook).

Class sizes are limited. Deadline to sign up is tomorrow - http://ow.ly/SBAm50ArUZv

Questions? Contact Julie at jries@sspps.org

𝐏𝐚𝐧𝐝𝐞𝐦𝐢𝐜 𝐄𝐥𝐞𝐜𝐭𝐫𝐨𝐧𝐢𝐜 𝐁𝐞𝐧𝐞𝐟𝐢𝐭 𝐓𝐫𝐚𝐧𝐬𝐟𝐞𝐫 (𝐏-𝐄𝐁𝐓) 𝐟𝐨𝐫 𝐅𝐚𝐦𝐢𝐥𝐢𝐞𝐬 𝐨𝐟 𝐒𝐭𝐮𝐝𝐞𝐧𝐭𝐬 𝐐𝐮𝐚𝐥𝐢𝐟𝐲𝐢𝐧𝐠 𝐟𝐨𝐫 𝐅𝐫𝐞𝐞 𝐚𝐧𝐝 𝐑𝐞𝐝𝐮𝐜𝐞𝐝-𝐏𝐫𝐢𝐜𝐞 𝐌𝐞𝐚𝐥𝐬

The Minnesota Department of Human Services is now offering additional funds for the families of children ages 5 to 18 who qualify for free and reduced-price meals. This new program, called Pandemic EBT (P-EBT), will provide $325 per child that families can use to purchase nutritious food for their household. Families with children who received free or reduced-price meals at school, and who were between the ages of 5 and 18 on September 1, 2019, may qualify. Benefits are available to two groups. 𝐋𝐚𝐬𝐭 𝐝𝐚𝐲 𝐭𝐨 𝐜𝐨𝐦𝐩𝐥𝐞𝐭𝐞 𝐭𝐡𝐞 𝐚𝐩𝐩𝐥𝐢𝐜𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧 𝐢𝐬 𝐓𝐮𝐞𝐬𝐝𝐚𝐲, 𝐉𝐮𝐧𝐞 𝟑𝟎!

LEARN MORE here - https://www.sspps.org/Page/2835

The Minnesota Department of Human Services is now offering additional funds for the families of children ages 5 to 18 who qualify for free and reduced-price meals. This new program, called Pandemic EBT (P-EBT), will provide $325 per child that families can use to purchase nutritious food for their household. Families with children who received free or reduced-price meals at school, and who were between the ages of 5 and 18 on September 1, 2019, may qualify. Benefits are available to two groups. 𝐋𝐚𝐬𝐭 𝐝𝐚𝐲 𝐭𝐨 𝐜𝐨𝐦𝐩𝐥𝐞𝐭𝐞 𝐭𝐡𝐞 𝐚𝐩𝐩𝐥𝐢𝐜𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧 𝐢𝐬 𝐓𝐮𝐞𝐬𝐝𝐚𝐲, 𝐉𝐮𝐧𝐞 𝟑𝟎!

☀️𝐒𝐒𝐏 𝐒𝐚𝐟𝐞 𝐑𝐨𝐮𝐭𝐞𝐬 𝐢𝐧 𝐒𝐮𝐦𝐦𝐞𝐫! In partnership with SSP Parks & Rec and South St. Paul Public Library, South St. Paul Public Schools (SSPPS) Safe Routes to School Program is launching the SSP Safe Routes in Summer Campaign!

Mark your calendars for June 29 - July 31
Did you know July is National Park & Rec Month? It’s time to recognize the importance of parks and recreation in establishing and maintaining quality of life and in contributing to the physical,
economic, and environmental well-being of communities. The goal of this campaign is to highlight the benefits of local parks and recreation centers to our SSP community. We hope to encourage students, families, and community members to get outside, explore local parks, and enjoy outdoor activities!

Visit www.sspps.org/saferoutes for more information and learn how you can participate!

post_text:
𝐋𝐞𝐚𝐡 𝐁𝐨𝐮𝐫𝐠 𝐉𝐨𝐢𝐧𝐬 𝐒𝐨𝐮𝐭𝐡 𝐒𝐭. 𝐏𝐚𝐮𝐥 𝐒𝐜𝐡𝐨𝐨𝐥𝐬 𝐚𝐬 𝐌𝐢𝐝𝐝𝐥𝐞 𝐒𝐜𝐡𝐨𝐨𝐥 𝐏𝐫𝐢𝐧𝐜𝐢𝐩𝐚𝐥 - SSPPS is excited to announce Leah Bourg as the new middle school principal. Leah brings incredible leadership experience from all three levels of the school system (elementary, middle and high school). Leah has served as an administrator at Metcalf Middle School in Burnsville and Crossroads Elementary in St. Paul. She also has 10 years of International Baccalaureate teaching experience. Leah has experience establishing and leading Positive Behavioral Interventions and Supports (PBIS) and Multi-Tiered Systems of Support (MTSS) to increase student achievement and improve building climate. Throughout her years, she has also been a leader and teacher of technology for her colleagues.

READ MORE here - http://ow.ly/PyMr50AbqY2

#SSPpride

𝐒𝐒𝐏 𝐬𝐞𝐞𝐤𝐢𝐧𝐠 𝐧𝐚𝐦𝐞 𝐫𝐞𝐜𝐨𝐦𝐦𝐞𝐧𝐝𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧𝐬 𝐟𝐨𝐫 𝐧𝐞𝐰 𝐂𝐋𝐂 𝐚𝐧𝐝 𝐂𝐨𝐦𝐦𝐮𝐧𝐢𝐭𝐲 𝐄𝐝𝐮𝐜𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧 𝐛𝐮𝐢𝐥𝐝𝐢𝐧𝐠 𝐭𝐡𝐫𝐨𝐮𝐠𝐡 𝐉𝐮𝐧𝐞 𝟑𝟎 - Starting this fall, the building will house the Community Learning Center (CLC), the district adult learning programs and Community Education offices.

SSP is excited about this new addition and invites the community to submit recommendations for the school name. Name suggestions will be reviewed by a naming committee, which includes a number of staff and two School Board representatives. The naming committee will bring forward their top recommendations to the superintendent in early July, who will then make recommendations to the School Board. The board will be asked to take action to approve a name for the new building in late July.

𝗦𝘂𝗴𝗴𝗲𝘀𝘁 𝗮 𝗻𝗮𝗺𝗲 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗯𝘂𝗶𝗹𝗱𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗵𝗲𝗿𝗲 - http://ow.ly/B7mZ50AbqsJ
The deadline for name submissions is Tuesday, June 30.

💚𝐒𝐜𝐡𝐨𝐨𝐥-𝐥𝐢𝐧𝐤𝐞𝐝 𝐦𝐞𝐧𝐭𝐚𝐥 𝐡𝐞𝐚𝐥𝐭𝐡 𝐬𝐮𝐩𝐩𝐨𝐫𝐭𝐬 𝐚𝐫𝐞 𝐚𝐯𝐚𝐢𝐥𝐚𝐛𝐥𝐞 𝐭𝐨 𝐬𝐭𝐮𝐝𝐞𝐧𝐭𝐬 - Emotional ups and downs are to be expected during this time of COVID crisis, but if your child is experiencing any of the following, please consider reaching out for some extra support:

✅Increased problems in multiple areas of life: academic, social, family relationships, etc.
✅Excessive worry
✅Crying, hopelessness, or feeling sad
✅Significant changes in sleeping or eating habits
✅Feeling bad about themselves
✅Withdrawal from activities or relationships they used to enjoy
✅Engaging in negative behaviors
✅Self harm behaviors or statements like “I wish I weren’t here”

The Associated Clinic of Psychology (ACP) was awarded a grant by the Minnesota Department of Human Services (DHS) to provide school and community based therapy to students and their families throughout Dakota County, regardless of their insurance coverage.

Visit https://www.sspps.org/Page/2832 for more information.

💻𝐊-𝟏𝟐 𝐒𝐭𝐮𝐝𝐞𝐧𝐭 𝐃𝐞𝐯𝐢𝐜𝐞 𝐚𝐧𝐝 𝐁𝐨𝐨𝐤 𝐑𝐞𝐭𝐮𝐫𝐧 📚

Dear SSP students and families, SSPPS is collecting all district-issued student devices, textbooks and library material Wednesday through Friday, June 3-5! These dates include collection from seniors who have not yet turned in their devices.

Please return your student devices and books, unless your student has been told by a summer program administrator to keep their device, 𝐰𝐞 𝐧𝐞𝐞𝐝 𝐭𝐡𝐞𝐦 𝐛𝐚𝐜𝐤 𝐭𝐨 𝐞𝐧𝐬𝐮𝐫𝐞 𝐭𝐡𝐚𝐭 𝐰𝐞 𝐡𝐚𝐯𝐞 𝐞𝐧𝐨𝐮𝐠𝐡 𝐰𝐨𝐫𝐤𝐢𝐧𝐠 𝐝𝐞𝐯𝐢𝐜𝐞𝐬 𝐟𝐨𝐫 𝐬𝐮𝐦𝐦𝐞𝐫 𝐬𝐜𝐡𝐨𝐨𝐥 𝐚𝐧𝐝 𝐟𝐚𝐥𝐥.

Details on schedule, route map, what to bring and how to return are here - http://ow.ly/Tz6R50zYlQv

If you have already returned your students’ devices, thank you and have a great summer!

post_text:
This week's Golden Abe Award goes to Mrs. Jensen's 1st Grade class. Students listened to the book "If You Give a Mouse a Brownie" and shared their favorite part of the book through drawings and message recording. Several students liked the part where the mouse looks up at the clouds and suddenly wanted some ice cream. Other students shared their favorite part was when the mouse started a rock band and performed a concert.

Students have also been learning about life cycles of ladybugs, chickens and frogs. They selected an animal they were interested in and did research on the habitats and other interesting facts.

🎉Shout out to all 1st graders in Mrs. Jensen's class! Way to go! #SSPpride #SSPlearns

This week's Golden Abe Award goes to both Mrs. Gerken and Mrs. McAlpine’s 2nd grade classes! Students have been busy with distance learning. They visited the "Three Little Pigs Mystery Room" where they got to choose different books to read. Students selected their favorite book and then shared with their classmates which book they liked best and why. Students were creative and descriptive in their responses. Great work!

🎉Shout out to all 2nd graders in Mrs. Gerken & Mrs. McAlpine’s classes! Way to go! #SSPpride #SSPlearns

Amari has been principled by focusing on his school work; he has been a risk-taker by learning how to adjust to distance learning; he has been caring by reaching out to his classmates; and he has been very flexible with adjusting to all of the new things with school at home!

Good work, Amari!

post_text:
This week's Golden Abe Award goes to two groups of students - Mrs. Derryberry and Mrs. Baxter’s kindergarten classes! Students have been busy with distance learning. Students listened to the book "Who’s In The Shed?" and creatively shared their ideas for the ending of the story. Some students drew pictures, while others wrote their thoughts as to who they thought was in the shed. Students were also busy working on practicing their CVC words and completing their site word lists. Way to go!

🎉Shout out to all kindergartners in Mrs. Derryberry and Mrs. Baxter’s classes! Way to go! #SSPpride #SSPlearns

post_text:
💚𝐌𝐚𝐲 𝐢𝐬 𝐌𝐞𝐧𝐭𝐚𝐥 𝐇𝐞𝐚𝐥𝐭𝐡 𝐌𝐨𝐧𝐭𝐡 - UMN School Psychologist intern, Ms. Klaft shares how to find the positives after a loss, especially during this time. A loss isn't just the death of a loved one; it could be a loss of your job, your home, your daliy routines, not being able to socialize with friends/families; it could also be missing out on timeless traditions like birthday celebrations, graduation, etc.; or it could be a loss of your favorite restaurants.

After watching the video, Ms. Klaft would like to challenge you to focus on the positives today and practice gratitude by keeping a tally of the positive things that happened during the day.

#SSPpride #SSPcares #SSPlearns #NotAlone #stopthestigma #mentalhealthmonth

A loss isn't just the death of a loved one; it could be a loss of your job, your home, your daliy routines, not being able to socialize with friends/families; it could also be missing out on timeless traditions like birthday celebrations, graduation, etc.; or it could be a loss of your favorite restaurants.

post_text:
🎉 #SSPpride 4th grader Ashlyn won the Lincoln Center Principal Praise award! Ashlyn has been a thinker and an inquirer while switching to distance learning. When she gets to a task that is difficult or unfamiliar, she asks good questions and perseveres until she figures it out. She has shown a lot of dedication to learning over the past two weeks. She has also done an excellent job working on her growth mindset!

Good work, Ashlyn!

#SScares #SSPlearns

𝐈𝐭'𝐬 𝐁𝐢𝐤𝐞 𝐚𝐧𝐝 𝐖𝐚𝐥𝐤 𝐀𝐧𝐲𝐰𝐡𝐞𝐫𝐞 𝐖𝐞𝐞𝐤 𝐚𝐭 𝐒𝐒𝐏! 🚶‍♀️Today's theme is Mindful Walking. Join us in being observant and mindful as we start the week. Take a mindful walk. Try walking barefoot in the grass, moving slowly from heel to the ball of the toes, notice the ground, the texture, the temperature, the small bumps.

Try it out and share your experience with us!

post_text:
This week's Golden Abe Award goes to Mr. Swanson's 4th grade class! Students were busy this week with numerous distance learning activities. Students were actively connected to their peers and with Mr. Swanson in a variety of ways. Students had the opportunity to watch Mrs. Gysbers' video and explore various career paths. Mr. Swanson recorded a video for students that demonstrated how they could connect via Google Meets, and they were also able to share work completion/habits data by taking a class survey.

🎉Shout out to all 4th graders in Mr. Swanson's class! Way to go!

#SSPpride #SSPlearns

post_text:
🚴‍♀️Today is SSP Bike to Anywhere Day! 🚴‍♂️ While we won’t be able to get together in person for large-scale events like ‘Bike to School Day’ this spring, we hope individual students and families will get outside on a walk or bike ride when possible. To that end, we are rolling out an alternative to national ‘Bike to School Day’ this spring… Bike to Anywhere Day!

That’s right, this year we want you to choose your own adventure to celebrate biking and fill in that blank! Use hashtag #SSPbikes to share where you adventured to!

Family bike rides and walks are great ways to stay active and de-stress during the COVOID-19 outbreak as long as you follow social distancing rules and stay 6 ft away from anyone who is not in your family. Be outside and celebrate the joy of active movement!

📸Share your photos/videos with us at socialmedia@sspps.org.

post_text:
𝐓𝐡𝐢𝐬 𝐰𝐞𝐞𝐤'𝐬 𝐭𝐡𝐞𝐦𝐞𝐬 𝐚𝐫𝐞 𝐝𝐞𝐝𝐢𝐜𝐚𝐭𝐞𝐝 𝐭𝐨 𝐓𝐞𝐚𝐜𝐡𝐞𝐫 𝐀𝐩𝐩𝐫𝐞𝐜𝐢𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧 𝐖𝐞𝐞𝐤! Teachers change the lives of our children every day—their immense work and impact moves us beyond words. And with the abrupt end to the physical school year, our teachers have done even more to continue education with virtual classrooms and learning at home lessons. All to ensure every student has the tools they need to reach their full potential.

So, let’s all shower teachers in appreciation and share how we love (❤️) like (👍), celebrate (🎉) and care for (😍) our teachers!

📸 Share photos/videos with us at socialmedia@sspps.org.

#SSPcares #SSPlearns

post_text:
This week's Golden Abe Award goes to Mrs. Borrell's 5th grade class! 👩‍🌾 Students used their creativity and shared ideas of their ideal imaginary garden during their Morning Meeting Check In. Student gardens included a variety of fruits, vegetables, grains, and even some flowers. Some wanted to plant tulips, pumpkins, tomatoes, strawberries, asparagus, carrots, watermelon, corn, cucumbers, grapes, and an apple tree. Some students shared Mrs. Borrell’s love of raspberries, and a student also included wheat so he could make bread.

Shout out to all 5th graders in Mrs. Borrell's class! Way to go! #SSPpride 🎉

What would you like to plant in a garden?

💆‍♀️Just a friendly reminder that there is no distance learning today! Take this day to relax, spend some quality time with family or yourself, or maybe bake some cookies!

Today's Virtual Spirit theme is also Encouragement Day. Brighten someone's day with encouraging chalk notes on your driveway/sidewalks! Be sure to share it with us so we can brighten everyone's day!

#SSPpride #SSPcares #SSPlearns

post_text:
𝙄𝙣 𝙘𝙖𝙨𝙚 𝙮𝙤𝙪 𝙢𝙞𝙨𝙨𝙚𝙙 𝙩𝙝𝙚 𝙛𝙖𝙢𝙞𝙡𝙮 𝙪𝙥𝙙𝙖𝙩𝙚 𝙨𝙚𝙣𝙩 𝙤𝙪𝙩 𝙩𝙝𝙞𝙨 𝙚𝙫𝙚𝙣𝙞𝙣𝙜:

This afternoon Gov. Walz ordered all Minnesota public schools to continue distance learning while schools and buildings remain closed for the remainder of the 2019-2020 school year.

I know this is disappointing news and you likely have many questions about your child’s education and upcoming spring/summer events. District leaders have been planning for the possibility of extended school closures and are now working through the new executive orders shared by Gov. Walz today. Over the coming days and weeks we will share additional plans and details as they become available.

In the meantime, here are some details of how we will continue operating in SSPPS. READ FULL UPDATE here - http://ow.ly/bEAn50zn8Pq

post_text:
Sam is a humble and inquisitive learner who devotes the time needed to achieve mastery. He is always willing to help his fellow classmates when they do not understand the topics. Sam does not expect recognition for helping others; he does it for the satisfaction of seeing his peers learn the material.

Every trimester, South St. Paul Secondary recognizes #SSPpride high school students on the Wall of Fame in the following categories: academic, character, IB and service.

post_text:
This week's Golden Abe Award goes to Mrs. Bauer's 2nd grade class! Students shared updates of how they spent their weekend during their Morning Check In meetings. Some of these activities include calling relatives, playing board games, riding bikes, baking cakes, bringing food to neighbors, playing outside, Face-timing cousins, watching movies, participating in egg hunts (inside and outside), building castles, and much more. Thank you 2nd graders for showing your creativity, kindness, and being risk-takers!

Shout out to all 2nd graders in Mrs. Bauer's class! Way to go! #SSPpride 🎉

post_text:
Mr. Truhler provides weekly social-emotional lessons online. In this video, he talks about what is self-awareness, the importance of understanding our emotions, strengths and challenges, and how our emotions affect our behavior and decisions. But first, you have to try to beat Mr. Truhler at Rock Paper Scissors... 🆗✊✋✌️

Visit https://sites.google.com/view/sel-site/home?authuser=0 for more social-emotional resources and follow Mr. Truhler's weekly lessons!

post_text:
𝗗𝗜𝗗 𝗬𝗢𝗨 𝗞𝗡𝗢𝗪? If at any time during the school year your family income status changes (e.g. laid-off, furlough, government shutdown, seasonal work), you are encouraged to 𝗰𝗼𝗺𝗽𝗹𝗲𝘁𝗲 𝗮𝗻 𝗔𝗽𝗽𝗹𝗶𝗰𝗮𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝗘𝗱𝘂𝗰𝗮𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻𝗮𝗹 𝗕𝗲𝗻𝗲𝗳𝗶𝘁𝘀. 🍎Once approved for free/reduced priced meal benefits, they are in place for the remainder of the school year, regardless of income status.

Parents can apply online at www.schoolcafe.com, or submit paper application via mail/fax.

* * * * *
𝐖𝐡𝐚𝐭 𝐚𝐫𝐞 𝐭𝐡𝐞 𝐛𝐞𝐧𝐞𝐟𝐢𝐭𝐬 𝐨𝐟 𝐫𝐞-𝐚𝐩𝐩𝐥𝐲𝐢𝐧𝐠 𝐚𝐧𝐝 𝐠𝐞𝐭𝐭𝐢𝐧𝐠 𝐚𝐩𝐩𝐫𝐨𝐯𝐞𝐝?

1️⃣ Your student(s) will be eligible for free/reduced price for this school year AND the first 30 days into the next school year, regardless of income status.

2️⃣ You may be currently receiving internet at no cost for distance learning, your household will still be eligible to receive internet at a lower cost in the future.

* * * * *
𝐐𝐮𝐞𝐬𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧𝐬 𝐨𝐫 𝐧𝐞𝐞𝐝 𝐚𝐬𝐬𝐢𝐬𝐭𝐚𝐧𝐜𝐞 𝐢𝐧 𝐜𝐨𝐦𝐩𝐥𝐞𝐭𝐢𝐧𝐠 𝐭𝐡𝐞 𝐚𝐩𝐩𝐥𝐢𝐜𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧?
Please contact our Nutrition Services office at 651-457-9429.
Paper applications also available at https://www.sspps.org/Page/311.

#SSPcares #SSPpride

🚨𝐃𝐢𝐬𝐭𝐚𝐧𝐜𝐞 𝐋𝐞𝐚𝐫𝐧𝐢𝐧𝐠 𝐒𝐮𝐫𝐯𝐞𝐲 𝐟𝐨𝐫 𝐅𝐚𝐦𝐢𝐥𝐢𝐞𝐬 🚨
You can find the survey here - www.sspps.org/distancelearning-survey

On Monday, March 30, 2020, SSPPS started a new chapter in our educational journey with the launch of our Distance Learning Plan. Understanding that this is new for all of us, we are seeking input and feedback from you about the learning experiences of your child(ren) over the last two weeks.

Your responses will help us understand the effectiveness of our Distance Learning Plan and identify areas where we can improve to better support your child(ren).

The information you provide is confidential and is not connected to your child's educational record. All items on the survey are optional.

post_text: 🧐Need ideas what to do at home while practicing social distancing? Student leaders from Comunidad de Latinos Unidos (CDLU) have some ideas for you! #SSPpride #SSPcares
text: 🧐Need ideas what to do at home while practicing social distancing? Student leaders from Comunidad de Latinos Unidos (CDLU) have some ideas for you! #SSPpride #SSPcares

post_text:
𝐓𝐨𝐝𝐚𝐲 𝐀𝐩𝐫𝐢𝐥 𝟏 𝐢𝐬 𝟐𝟎𝟐𝟎 𝐂𝐞𝐧𝐬𝐮𝐬 𝐃𝐚𝐲! Sing along this song and make sure to complete your household's census online, by phone, or by mail!

🤷‍♀️ 𝐖𝐇𝐘 𝐢𝐬 𝐭𝐡𝐢𝐬 𝐢𝐦𝐩𝐨𝐫𝐭𝐚𝐧𝐭 𝐚𝐧𝐝 𝐡𝐨𝐰 𝐝𝐨𝐞𝐬 𝐢𝐬 𝐚𝐟𝐟𝐞𝐜𝐭 𝐲𝐨𝐮𝐫 𝐬𝐜𝐡𝐨𝐨𝐥𝐬?
Responses to the census help schools plan for the resources they will need when the new generation of children is ready for school. Some of the federal funding based on census statistics is for services that influence students’ readiness for learning, including maternal and child health programs, and housing, heating and food assistance.

When it comes to schools, the 2020 Census will also help determine funding for special education, teacher training, technology, school lunch assistance, Head Start and after-school programs.

More information available at www.sspps.org/census2020 or https://2020census.gov.

Video by U.S. Census Bureau.
text:
𝐓𝐨𝐝𝐚𝐲 𝐀𝐩𝐫𝐢𝐥 𝟏 𝐢𝐬 𝟐𝟎𝟐𝟎 𝐂𝐞𝐧𝐬𝐮𝐬 𝐃𝐚𝐲! Sing along this song and make sure to complete your household's census online, by phone, or by mail!

🤷‍♀️ 𝐖𝐇𝐘 𝐢𝐬 𝐭𝐡𝐢𝐬 𝐢𝐦𝐩𝐨𝐫𝐭𝐚𝐧𝐭 𝐚𝐧𝐝 𝐡𝐨𝐰 𝐝𝐨𝐞𝐬 𝐢𝐬 𝐚𝐟𝐟𝐞𝐜𝐭 𝐲𝐨𝐮𝐫 𝐬𝐜𝐡𝐨𝐨𝐥𝐬?
Responses to the census help schools plan for the resources they will need when the new generation of children is ready for school. Some of the federal funding based on census statistics is for services that influence students’ readiness for learning, including maternal and child health programs, and housing, heating and food assistance.

When it comes to schools, the 2020 Census will also help determine funding for special education, teacher training, technology, school lunch assistance, Head Start and after-school programs.

More information available at www.sspps.org/census2020 or https://2020census.gov.

Video by U.S. Census Bureau.

post_text:
𝐍𝐞𝐞𝐝 𝐬𝐨𝐦𝐞𝐭𝐡𝐢𝐧𝐠 𝐭𝐨 𝐝𝐨 𝐚𝐭 𝐡𝐨𝐦𝐞? 𝐖𝐞𝐥𝐥, 𝐢𝐭'𝐬 𝐭𝐢𝐦𝐞 𝐭𝐨 𝐫𝐞𝐬𝐩𝐨𝐧𝐝 𝐭𝐨 𝐭𝐡𝐞 𝟐𝟎𝟐𝟎 𝐜𝐞𝐧𝐬𝐮𝐬! Household will begin receiving official Census Bureau mail with detailed information on how to respond to the 2020 Census online, by phone, or by mail.

🤷‍♀️ 𝐖𝐇𝐘 𝐢𝐬 𝐭𝐡𝐢𝐬 𝐢𝐦𝐩𝐨𝐫𝐭𝐚𝐧𝐭 𝐚𝐧𝐝 𝐡𝐨𝐰 𝐝𝐨𝐞𝐬 𝐢𝐬 𝐚𝐟𝐟𝐞𝐜𝐭 𝐲𝐨𝐮𝐫 𝐬𝐜𝐡𝐨𝐨𝐥𝐬?
Responses to the census help schools plan for the resources they will need when the new generation of children is ready for school. Some of the federal funding based on census statistics is for services that influence students’ readiness for learning, including maternal and child health programs, and housing, heating and food assistance.

When it comes to schools, the 2020 Census will also help determine funding for special education, teacher training, technology, school lunch assistance, Head Start and after-school programs.

More information available at www.sspps.org/census2020 or https://2020census.gov.

Thank you for helping us spread the word on the Emergency School Meals program! We were able to serve over 400 SSP children on the first day of this program yesterday!

Here are a couple things you could do to help make things run smoother:
🐶 Please refrain from bringing pets when picking up school meals. Staff/children may be allergic to certain pets.
🎒 Consider bringing reusable bags to carry your meals home.

✌🏻Come and grab your school meals between 11am and 1:35pm today!

Visit www.sspps.org/emergency-school-meals for more information on drop-off locations and time.

#SSPpride #SSPcares

post_text:
𝐂𝐎𝐕𝐈𝐃-𝟏𝟗 𝐔𝐏𝐃𝐀𝐓𝐄

While Gov. Walz has declared a state of emergency for Minnesota, the Commissioner of Health and other health officials continue to warn 𝙖𝙜𝙖𝙞𝙣𝙨𝙩 broad school closures at this time given current information available.

However, in order to prepare for a possible closure in the future, the district decided to extend spring break for students by two extra days to allow time for SSPPS staff to prepare for a potential future closure if called.

Therefore, SSPPS classes will be canceled for students on Monday, March 16, and Tuesday, March 17, 2020, so that district staff can do extra planning for COVID-19 (coronavirus).

READ FULL UPDATE here - http://ow.ly/OuWS50yLqht

Please note that it is our understanding that Governor Walz may make an additional announcement about the coronavirus this afternoon, which may provide additional guidance to school. To that end, we ask you to stay tuned as we may have new information to share later today and/or over the weekend.

Full update available at www.sspps.org/coronavirus.

post_text:
𝐒𝐜𝐡𝐨𝐨𝐥 𝐁𝐨𝐚𝐫𝐝 𝐚𝐩𝐩𝐫𝐨𝐯𝐞𝐬 𝐚𝐜𝐚𝐝𝐞𝐦𝐢𝐜 𝐜𝐚𝐥𝐞𝐧𝐝𝐚𝐫𝐬 𝐟𝐨𝐫 𝐭𝐡𝐞 𝐧𝐞𝐱𝐭 𝐭𝐰𝐨 𝐲𝐞𝐚𝐫𝐬

At its meeting on March 9, the SSP School Board approved the academic calendars for the 2020-21 and 2021-22 school years. In both school years, SSP students will start school the fall on the Tuesday after Labor Day, and the last day for students is scheduled for the second week of June.

READ MORE here - http://ow.ly/1ksM50yI1bG

Calendars are available to download at www.sspps.org/calendar.

post_text: 🎉 #SSPpride 5th grader Angelo won the Lincoln Center Principal Praise award! Angelo is kind to all students and remains responsible and principled at school. He is also a classroom leader and follows all student expectations. Keep up the good work, Angelo!

It's time for another #SSPpride #TBT!

This week we're throwing it back to late 2000s. Can you guess the year? Who do you recognize?
text:
It's time for another #SSPpride #TBT!

This week we're throwing it back to late 2000s. Can you guess the year? Who do you recognize?

post_text:
𝐈𝐧𝐧𝐨𝐯𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐯𝐞 𝐩𝐚𝐫𝐭𝐧𝐞𝐫𝐬𝐡𝐢𝐩 𝐨𝐟𝐟𝐞𝐫𝐬 𝐬𝐩𝐞𝐜𝐢𝐚𝐥 𝐞𝐝𝐮𝐜𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧, 𝐦𝐞𝐧𝐭𝐚𝐥 𝐡𝐞𝐚𝐥𝐭𝐡 𝐬𝐮𝐩𝐩𝐨𝐫𝐭 𝐟𝐨𝐫 𝐒𝐨𝐮𝐭𝐡 𝐒𝐭. 𝐏𝐚𝐮𝐥 𝐬𝐭𝐮𝐝𝐞𝐧𝐭𝐬 𝐚𝐭 𝐫𝐞𝐝𝐮𝐜𝐞𝐝 𝐜𝐨𝐬𝐭

Through an innovative partnership between South Saint Paul Public Schools (SSPPS) and the University of Minnesota, more consistent special education and mental health services are able to be offered to students at a reduced cost to the district. The partnership provides much needed support to students while also ensuring school psychologist graduate students gain the in-school experience they need to attain their degree.

READ MORE here - http://ow.ly/FyX850yD8dE
text:
𝐈𝐧𝐧𝐨𝐯𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐯𝐞 𝐩𝐚𝐫𝐭𝐧𝐞𝐫𝐬𝐡𝐢𝐩 𝐨𝐟𝐟𝐞𝐫𝐬 𝐬𝐩𝐞𝐜𝐢𝐚𝐥 𝐞𝐝𝐮𝐜𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧, 𝐦𝐞𝐧𝐭𝐚𝐥 𝐡𝐞𝐚𝐥𝐭𝐡 𝐬𝐮𝐩𝐩𝐨𝐫𝐭 𝐟𝐨𝐫 𝐒𝐨𝐮𝐭𝐡 𝐒𝐭. 𝐏𝐚𝐮𝐥 𝐬𝐭𝐮𝐝𝐞𝐧𝐭𝐬 𝐚𝐭 𝐫𝐞𝐝𝐮𝐜𝐞𝐝 𝐜𝐨𝐬𝐭

Through an innovative partnership between South Saint Paul Public Schools (SSPPS) and the University of Minnesota, more consistent special education and mental health services are able to be offered to students at a reduced cost to the district. The partnership provides much needed support to students while also ensuring school psychologist graduate students gain the in-school experience they need to attain their degree.
